is one of those largely unknown historic cities in the

with a tale of its own. It doesn't see too many visitors today, but the old centre still holds monumental buildings from former glory days and is famous for its fruits production. When you're in the Netherlands in May, Tiel is an excellent base to explore the lovely Betuwe orchards in bloom. In September, the city is the stage for the largest free pop music festival in the country: Appelpop, as well as for a flower parade. Although mid-sized, this is the largest city in the Betuwe area.

value: was once a famous marketing cartoon for a fruit factory

In the 20th century, Tiel became a major fruit production centre. The city's mascot is still a little boy called

, who looks a whole lot like a raspberry with arms and legs. The figure was used for marketing by a large fruit and jam factory that stopped operations here in the 1990's, but remains the city's mascot. 
Many locals consider Tiel to be a largely industrial town, but for those prepared to look, there's plenty of older, interesting history around.
passes by here, and the main roads into town are the
. The main Tiel train station has direct sprinter train connections to
, as well as a slower "stop train" connection to

, only the train to Utrecht stops. Trains run every half hour.

For most travellers, the train is the most convenient form of public transport when coming here. Nonetheless, Tiel is served by a range of buses, operated mainly by Arriva. They run mostly to and from smaller towns in the area, including line
(from where its possible to change for

Walk your way around the centre, as it's the best way to see the monuments up close. For the surroundings however, a bicycle will allow for further explorations of the orchards and pretty, rural landscapes. You can rent one at:

value: price=€10 for a day, plus a €50 deposit which will be returned when the bike is back without damage.
content=This place rents different kinds of bicycles (e.g. with and without gear). Bikes can be picked up from 8.30 and returned until 17.30.
Parts of the former city walls remain, such as here, near the Tolhuiswal.

The many orchards in the region provide a most lovely view in May, when the thousands of fruit trees are in bloom. The sight is an attraction on its own, and best appreciated by a hike or bike trip.

The town itself has a number if historic buildings, several dating back to the 17th century when Tiel was a flourishing town surrounded by
. Parts of the walls are still in tact, and the
in the west of town is a good place to see them. Other highlights include:

value: content=The original Water Gate originated in 1647 but was destroyed during the final days of WWII. It was entirely rebuild in 1979. High on the façade is the city's coat of arms, with the words
. The Latin memorial plaque originates in 1528, but was initially place on another gate, the Brunense Poort, which was demolished in 1853.
content=This large, Gothic church was built in the 1420's-1430's. Although repeatedly changed and never entirely finished, it's a large building and used for services until today.
hours=Second Fri and Sa of September

content=If you happen to be around in September, you might be able to take in the largest free music festival in the country. The line-up consists mostly of national artists, including many of the most popular ones, but also sees some international artists.

content=This September festival sees a parade of colourful, creative cars - decorated from top to bottom with fruits, seeds and flowers. Cars are at least 14 meters long, making for an impressive collection. The parade is usually organized the third weekend of September, and runs through the city centre.

The city's compact and car-free shopping area has a descent collection of shops and a nice atmosphere. Saturdays draw in shopping crowds from the Betuwe region, creating a lively buzz and full outdoor terraces in summer. The main area consists of the

for smaller boutique stores.

At the

, the main square where you'll also find cafés, markets are held on Saturdays (9.00-17.00h) and Mondays (12.00-17.00h). 

In terms of local specialities,
top the list, as the are is famous for both.
There are plenty of places to eat. If you have no reservation, try the
, where a bunch of cafés and restaurants are situated.

value: content=Nice atmosphere and a good, French and international menu. High quality ingredients and dishes make this place excellent value for money. The staff is helpful and friendly.
price=€25 for All you can eat

content=A modernly decorated restaurant, with coloured led-lightning all around. All-you-can-eat sushi and teppanyaki dishes is what most regular customers come here for. It's the best Japanese place in town and it does take-away too.

content=The historic building this restaurant sits in, makes it a lovely place for both lunch and dinner. It serves a wide range of dishes, including simple breads, eggs and soups for lunch, and a more extensive warm menu for the evening. They take pride in their classic fried sole dish (€27.50). Of course you're welcome at other times for coffee and cake, or even a high tea.

There's no nightlife scene to speak of, and locals tend to head elsewhere for a proper night out. Of course, cold drinks and chats can be had in one of the town's cafés. The
is the place to go, with outdoor terraces in summer and a number of places to choose from.

Places to stay in or directly around town are hard to come by, due to the limited number of visitors for this city. If you can't find what you're looking for, consider staying in the countryside (where some charming, small scale bed&breakfast are among the best choices) or sleep in nearby

value: content=One of the few choices in the city itself, this is a standard and adequate hotel in the Van der Valk chain. Rooms aren't all very up to date but otherwise fine. Some, especially the more expensive rooms as well as the lobby, have been upgraded. Staff is friendly and there's an on-site sushi restaurant.

content=This quaint hotel lies just across the river Waal, in the village of Wamel (part of Tiel municipality). A passenger ferry connects the village to the city, making it quite convenient to here instead of in the centre, even for those who wish to explore the city. It's also great for trips into the countryside, as they rent out bikes and allow for recharge of electric bicycles.
price=camp spots €12 for 2 p.p.n, huts €35 per night for 2p.,

content=Suited well for outdoor lovers and budget travellers, this place outside town offers camping spots as well as ready to use huts (with private bath and kitchenette) and caravans. It's situated along the river and rents out bikes and canoes. Note that they only accept cash payments. It's a 5 minute walk from the regional Tiel Passewaai station.
content=Close to the Flipje Streekmuseum, this is one of the convenient post offices in the city centre.
